newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia drafts A$5 bln standby tax plan - paper.
newsitem.headline: Australia drafts A$5 bln standby tax plan - paper.

text.p: The Australian government has drafted an emergency A$5 billion tax package to replace a string of state charges if a court challenge sees the state levies ruled invalid, a newspaper reported on Wednesday.

Australia's peak court, the High Court, will rule next Tuesday on a constitutional challenge to a New South Wales state tobacco business franchise fee in a decision that could affect scores of other state taxes, The Australian Financial Review said.
The paper said the taxes under threat were business franchise fees on tobacco, alcohol and petrol, which account for about 16 percent of state and territory revenue.

The New South Wales fee is being challenged under a section of the constitution which gives the national government sole power to impose excises and customs duties. The paper did not say who was making the challenge and court officials could not be immediately contacted.

Canberra has not revealed details of the emergency package, but a similar proposal drafted by the former Labor government in 1993 planned to levy a new federal tax at the highest state rate and hand the money back to the states and territories.
